Reference documentation for deal.II version 10.0.0-pre
\(\newcommand{\dealvcentcolon}{\mathrel{\mathop{:}}}\) \(\newcommand{\dealcoloneq}{\dealvcentcolon\mathrel{\mkern-1.2mu}=}\) \(\newcommand{\jump}[1]{\left[\!\left[ #1 \right]\!\right]}\) \(\newcommand{\average}[1]{\left\{\!\left\{ #1 \right\}\!\right\}}\)

step-69.h
Go to the documentation of this file.
1 
1483  } /* j */
1484  } /* q */
1485 *
1486  @endcode
1487 *
1488 * Now we have to compute the boundary normals. Note that the following loop does not do much unless the element has faces on the boundary of the domain.
1489 *
1490 
1491 *
1492 * @code
1493  for (const auto f : cell->face_indices())
1494  {
1495  const auto face = cell->face(f);
1496  const auto id = face->boundary_id();
1497 *
1498  if (!face->at_boundary())
1499  continue;
1500 *
1501  const auto &fe_face_values = scratch.reinit(cell, f);
1502 *
1503  const unsigned int n_face_q_points =
1504  fe_face_values.get_quadrature().size();
1505 *
1506  for (unsigned int j = 0; j < dofs_per_cell; ++j)
1507  {
1508  if (!discretization->finite_element.has_support_on_face(j, f))
1509  continue;
1510 *
1511  @endcode
1512 *
1513 * Note that "normal" will only represent the contributions from one of the faces in the support of the shape function phi_j. So we cannot normalize this local contribution right here, we have to take it "as is", store it and pass it to the copy data routine. The proper normalization requires an additional loop on nodes. This is done in the copy function below.
1514 *
1515 
1516 *
1517 * @code
1518  Tensor<1, dim> normal;
1519  if (id == Boundaries::free_slip)
1520  {
1521  for (unsigned int q = 0; q < n_face_q_points; ++q)
1522  normal += fe_face_values.normal_vector(q)
1523  fe_face_values.shape_value(j, q);
1524  }
1525 *
1526  const auto index = copy.local_dof_indices[j];
1527 *
1528  Point<dim> position;
1529  for (const auto v : cell->vertex_indices())
1530  if (cell->vertex_dof_index(v, 0) ==
1531  partitioner->local_to_global(index))
1532  {
1533  position = cell->vertex(v);
1534  break;
1535  }
1536 *
1537  const auto old_id =
1538  std::get<1>(copy.local_boundary_normal_map[index]);
1539  copy.local_boundary_normal_map[index] =
1540  std::make_tuple(normal, std::max(old_id, id), position);
1541  }
1542  }
1543  };
1544 *
1545  @endcode
1546 *
1547 * Last, we provide a copy_local_to_global function as required for the WorkStream
1548 *
1549 
1550 *
1551 * @code
1552  const auto copy_local_to_global = [&](const CopyData<dim> &copy) {
1553  if (copy.is_artificial)
1554  return;
1555 *
1556  for (const auto &it : copy.local_boundary_normal_map)
1557  {
1558  std::get<0>(boundary_normal_map[it.first]) +=
1559  std::get<0>(it.second);
1560  std::get<1>(boundary_normal_map[it.first]) =
1561  std::max(std::get<1>(boundary_normal_map[it.first]),
1562  std::get<1>(it.second));
1563  std::get<2>(boundary_normal_map[it.first]) = std::get<2>(it.second);
1564  }
1565 *
1566  lumped_mass_matrix.add(copy.local_dof_indices,
1567  copy.cell_lumped_mass_matrix);
1568 *
1569  for (int k = 0; k < dim; ++k)
1570  {
1571  cij_matrix[k].add(copy.local_dof_indices, copy.cell_cij_matrix[k]);
1572  nij_matrix[k].add(copy.local_dof_indices, copy.cell_cij_matrix[k]);
1573  }
1574  };
1575 *
1576  WorkStream::run(dof_handler.begin_active(),
1577  dof_handler.end(),
1578  local_assemble_system,
1579  copy_local_to_global,
1580  scratch_data,
1581  CopyData<dim>());
1582  }
1583 *
1584  @endcode
1585 *
1586 * At this point in time we are done with the computation of @f$m_i@f$ and @f$\mathbf{c}_{ij}@f$ , but so far the matrix <code>nij_matrix</code> contains just a copy of the matrix <code>cij_matrix</code> . That's not what we really want: we have to normalize its entries. In addition, we have not filled the entries of the matrix <code>norm_matrix</code> and the vectors stored in the map <code>OfflineData<dim>::BoundaryNormalMap</code> are not normalized.
1587 * In principle, this is just offline data, it doesn't make much sense to over-optimize their computation, since their cost will get amortized over the many time steps that we are going to use. However, computing/storing the entries of the matrix <code>norm_matrix</code> and the normalization of <code>nij_matrix</code> are perfect to illustrate thread-parallel node-loops:
1588 *
1589 
1590 *
1591 *
1592 * - we want to visit every node @f$i@f$ in the mesh/sparsity graph,
1593 *
1594 
1595 *
1596 *
1597 * - and for every such node we want to visit to every @f$j@f$ such that @f$\mathbf{c}_{ij} \not \equiv 0@f$ .
1598 * From an algebraic point of view, this is equivalent to: visiting every row in the matrix and for each one of these rows execute a loop on the columns. Node-loops is a core theme of this tutorial step (see the pseudo-code in the introduction) that will repeat over and over again. That's why this is the right time to introduce them.
1599 * We have the thread parallelization capability parallel::apply_to_subranges() that is somehow more general than the WorkStream framework. In particular, parallel::apply_to_subranges() can be used for our node-loops. This functionality requires four input arguments which we explain in detail (for the specific case of our thread-parallel node loops):
1600 *
1601 
1602 *
1603 *
1604 * - The iterator <code>indices.begin()</code> points to a row index.
1605 *
1606 
1607 *
1608 *
1609 * - The iterator <code>indices.end()</code> points to a numerically higher row index.
1610 *
1611 
1612 *
1613 *
1614 * - The function <code>on_subranges(i1,i2)</code> (where <code>i1</code> and <code>i2</code> define a sub-range within the range spanned by the end and begin iterators defined in the two previous bullets) applies an operation to every iterator in such subrange. We may as well call <code>on_subranges</code> the "worker".
1615 *
1616 
1617 *
1618 *
1619 * - Grainsize: minimum number of iterators (in this case representing rows) processed by each thread. We decided for a minimum of 4096 rows.
1620 * A minor caveat here is that the iterators <code>indices.begin()</code> and <code>indices.end()</code> supplied to parallel::apply_to_subranges() have to be random access iterators: internally, parallel::apply_to_subranges() will break the range defined by the <code>indices.begin()</code> and <code>indices.end()</code> iterators into subranges (we want to be able to read any entry in those subranges with constant complexity). In order to provide such iterators we resort to std_cxx20::ranges::iota_view.
1621 * The bulk of the following piece of code is spent defining the "worker" <code>on_subranges</code> : i.e. the operation applied at each row of the sub-range. Given a fixed <code>row_index</code> we want to visit every column/entry in such row. In order to execute such columns-loops we use <a href="http://www.cplusplus.com/reference/algorithm/for_each/">
1622  std::for_each</a> from the standard library, where:
1623 *
1624 
1625 *
1626 *
1627 * - <code>sparsity_pattern.begin(row_index)</code> gives us an iterator starting at the first column of the row,
1628 *
1629 
1630 *
1631 *
1632 * - <code>sparsity_pattern.end(row_index)</code> is an iterator pointing at the last column of the row,
1633 *
1634 
1635 *
1636 *
1637 * - the last argument required by `std::for_each` is the operation applied at each nonzero entry (a lambda expression in this case) of such row.
1638 * We note that, parallel::apply_to_subranges() will operate on disjoint sets of rows (the subranges) and our goal is to write into these rows. Because of the simple nature of the operations we want to carry out (computation and storage of normals, and normalization of the @f$\mathbf{c}_{ij}@f$ of entries) threads cannot conflict attempting to write the same entry (we do not need a scheduler).
1639 *
1640 
1641 *
1642 * @code
1643  {
1644  TimerOutput::Scope scope(computing_timer,
1645  "offline_data
1646 *
1647 - compute |c_ij|, and n_ij");
1648 *
1649  const std_cxx20::ranges::iota_view<unsigned int, unsigned int> indices(
1650  0, n_locally_relevant);
1651 *
1652  const auto on_subranges =
1653  [&](const auto i1, const auto i2) {
1654  for (const auto row_index :
1655  std_cxx20::ranges::iota_view<unsigned int, unsigned int>(*i1,
1656  i2))
1657  {
1658  @endcode
1659 *
1660 * First column-loop: we compute and store the entries of the matrix norm_matrix and write normalized entries into the matrix nij_matrix:
1661 *
1662 
1663 *
1664 * @code
1665  std::for_each(
1666  sparsity_pattern.begin(row_index),
1667  sparsity_pattern.end(row_index),
1668  [&](const ::SparsityPatternIterators::Accessor &jt) {
1669  const auto c_ij = gather_get_entry(cij_matrix, &jt);
1670  const double norm = c_ij.norm();
1671 *
1672  set_entry(norm_matrix, &jt, norm);
1673  for (unsigned int j = 0; j < dim; ++j)
1674  set_entry(nij_matrix[j], &jt, c_ij[j] / norm);
1675  });
1676  }
1677  };
1678 *
1679  parallel::apply_to_subranges(indices.begin(),
1680  indices.end(),
1681  on_subranges,
1682  4096);
1683 *
1684  @endcode
1685 *
1686 * Finally, we normalize the vectors stored in <code>OfflineData<dim>::BoundaryNormalMap</code> . This operation has not been thread parallelized as it would neither illustrate any important concept nor lead to any noticeable speed gain.
1687 *
1688 
1689 *
1690 * @code
1691  for (auto &it : boundary_normal_map)
1692  {
1693  auto &normal = std::get<0>(it.second);
1694  normal /= (normal.norm() + std::numeric_limits<double>::epsilon());
1695  }
1696  }
1697  }
1698 *
1699  @endcode
1700 *
1701 * At this point we are very much done with anything related to offline data.
1702 *
1703 
1704 *
1705 * <a name="EquationofstateandapproximateRiemannsolver"></a> <h4>Equation of state and approximate Riemann solver</h4>
1706 *
1707 
1708 *
1709 * In this section we describe the implementation of the class members of the <code>ProblemDescription</code> class. Most of the code here is specific to the compressible Euler's equations with an ideal gas law. If we wanted to re-purpose @ref step_69 "step-69" for a different conservation law (say for: instance the shallow water equation) most of the implementation of this class would have to change. But most of the other classes (in particular those defining loop structures) would remain unchanged.
1710 * We start by implementing a number of small member functions for computing <code>momentum</code>, <code>internal_energy</code> , <code>pressure</code>, <code>speed_of_sound</code> , and the flux <code>f</code> of the system. The functionality of each one of these functions is self-explanatory from their names.
1711 *
1712 
1713 *
1714 *
1715 
1716 *
1717 * @code
1718  template <int dim>
1719  DEAL_II_ALWAYS_INLINE inline Tensor<1, dim>
1720  ProblemDescription<dim>::momentum(const state_type &U)
1721  {
1722  Tensor<1, dim> result;
1723  std::copy_n(&U[1], dim, &result[0]);
1724  return result;
1725  }
1726 *
1727  template <int dim>
1728  DEAL_II_ALWAYS_INLINE inline double
1729  ProblemDescription<dim>::internal_energy(const state_type &U)
1730  {
1731  const double &rho = U[0];
1732  const auto m = momentum(U);
1733  const double &E = U[dim + 1];
1734  return E
1735 *
1736 - 0.5 m.norm_square() / rho;
1737  }
1738 *
1739  template <int dim>
1740  DEAL_II_ALWAYS_INLINE inline double
1741  ProblemDescription<dim>::pressure(const state_type &U)
1742  {
1743  return (gamma
1744 *
1745 - 1.) internal_energy(U);
1746  }
1747 *
1748  template <int dim>
1749  DEAL_II_ALWAYS_INLINE inline double
1750  ProblemDescription<dim>::speed_of_sound(const state_type &U)
1751  {
1752  const double &rho = U[0];
1753  const double p = pressure(U);
1754 *
1755  return std::sqrt(gamma p / rho);
1756  }
1757 *
1758  template <int dim>
1759  DEAL_II_ALWAYS_INLINE inline typename ProblemDescription<dim>::flux_type
1760  ProblemDescription<dim>::flux(const state_type &U)
1761  {
1762  const double &rho = U[0];
1763  const auto m = momentum(U);
1764  const auto p = pressure(U);
1765  const double &E = U[dim + 1];
1766 *
1767  flux_type result;
1768 *
1769  result[0] = m;
1770  for (unsigned int i = 0; i < dim; ++i)
1771  {
1772  result[1 + i] = m m[i] / rho;
1773  result[1 + i][i] += p;
1774  }
1775  result[dim + 1] = m / rho (E + p);
1776 *
1777  return result;
1778  }
1779 *
1780  @endcode
1781 *
1782 * Now we discuss the computation of @f$\lambda_{\text{max}}
1783  (\mathbf{U}_i^{n},\mathbf{U}_j^{n}, \textbf{n}_{ij})@f$ . The analysis and derivation of sharp upper-bounds of maximum wavespeeds of Riemann problems is a very technical endeavor and we cannot include an advanced discussion about it in this tutorial. In this portion of the documentation we will limit ourselves to sketch the main functionality of our implementation functions and point to specific academic references in order to help the (interested) reader trace the source (and proper mathematical justification) of these ideas.
1784 * In general, obtaining a sharp guaranteed upper-bound on the maximum wavespeed requires solving a quite expensive scalar nonlinear problem. This is typically done with an iterative solver. In order to simplify the presentation in this example step we decided not to include such an iterative scheme. Instead, we will just use an initial guess as a guess for an upper bound on the maximum wavespeed. More precisely, equations (2.11) (3.7), (3.8) and (4.3) of @cite GuermondPopov2016b are enough to define a guaranteed upper bound on the maximum wavespeed. This estimate is returned by a call to the function <code>lambda_max_two_rarefaction()</code> . At its core the construction of such an upper bound uses the so-called two-rarefaction approximation for the intermediate pressure @f$p^*@f$ , see for instance Equation (4.46), page 128 in @cite Toro2009 .
1785 * The estimate returned by <code>lambda_max_two_rarefaction()</code> is guaranteed to be an upper bound, it is in general quite sharp, and overall sufficient for our purposes. However, for some specific situations (in particular when one of states is close to vacuum conditions) such an estimate will be overly pessimistic. That's why we used a second estimate to avoid this degeneracy that will be invoked by a call to the function <code>lambda_max_expansion()</code> . The most important function here is <code>compute_lambda_max()</code> which takes the minimum between the estimates returned by <code>lambda_max_two_rarefaction()</code> and <code>lambda_max_expansion()</code> .
1786 * We start again by defining a couple of helper functions:
1787 * The first function takes a state <code>U</code> and a unit vector <code>n_ij</code> and computes the <i>projected</i> 1D state in direction of the unit vector.
1788 *
1789 
1790 *
1791 * @code
1792  namespace
1793  {
1794  template <int dim>
1795  DEAL_II_ALWAYS_INLINE inline std::array<double, 4> riemann_data_from_state(
1796  const typename ProblemDescription<dim>::state_type U,
1797  const Tensor<1, dim> & n_ij)
1798  {
1799  Tensor<1, 3> projected_U;
1800  projected_U[0] = U[0];
1801 *
1802  @endcode
1803 *
1804 * For this, we have to change the momentum to @f$\textbf{m}\cdot
1805  n_{ij}@f$ and have to subtract the kinetic energy of the perpendicular part from the total energy:
1806 *
1807 
1808 *
1809 * @code
1810  const auto m = ProblemDescription<dim>::momentum(U);
1811  projected_U[1] = n_ij m;
1812 *
1813  const auto perpendicular_m = m
1814 *
1815 - projected_U[1] n_ij;
1816  projected_U[2] = U[1 + dim]
1817 *
1818 - 0.5 perpendicular_m.norm_square() / U[0];
1819 *
1820  @endcode
1821 *
1822 * We return the 1D state in <i>primitive</i> variables instead of conserved quantities. The return array consists of density @f$\rho@f$ , velocity @f$u@f$ , pressure @f$p@f$ and local speed of sound @f$a@f$ :
1823 *
1824 
1825 *
1826 *
1827 
1828 *
1829 * @code
1830  return {{projected_U[0],
1831  projected_U[1] / projected_U[0],
1832  ProblemDescription<1>::pressure(projected_U),
1833  ProblemDescription<1>::speed_of_sound(projected_U)}};
1834  }
1835 *
1836  @endcode
1837 *
1838 * At this point we also define two small functions that return the positive and negative part of a double.
1839 *
1840 
1841 *
1842 *
1843 
1844 *
1845 * @code
1846  DEAL_II_ALWAYS_INLINE inline double positive_part(const double number)
1847  {
1848  return std::max(number, 0.);
1849  }
1850 *
1851 
1852  DEAL_II_ALWAYS_INLINE inline double negative_part(const double number)
1853  {
1854  return
1855 *
1856 -std::min(number, 0.);
1857  }
1858 *
1859  @endcode
1860 *
1861 * Next, we need two local wavenumbers that are defined in terms of a primitive state @f$[\rho, u, p, a]@f$ and a given pressure @f$p^\ast@f$ @cite GuermondPopov2016 Eqn. (3.7):
1862 
1863 *
1864 * @f{align*}
1865  \lambda^- = u
1866 *
1867 - a\,\sqrt{1 + \frac{\gamma+1}{2\gamma}
1868  \left(\frac{p^\ast-p}{p}\right)_+}
1869  @f}
1870 * Here, the @f$(\cdot)_{+}@f$ denotes the positive part of the given argument.
1871 *
1872 
1873 *
1874 *
1875 
1876 *
1877 * @code
1878  DEAL_II_ALWAYS_INLINE inline double
1879  lambda1_minus(const std::array<double, 4> &riemann_data,
1880  const double p_star)
1881  {
1882  /* Implements formula (3.7) in Guermond-Popov-2016 */
1883 *
1884  constexpr double gamma = ProblemDescription<1>::gamma;
1885  const auto u = riemann_data[1];
1886  const auto p = riemann_data[2];
1887  const auto a = riemann_data[3];
1888 *
1889  const double factor = (gamma + 1.0) / 2.0 / gamma;
1890  const double tmp = positive_part((p_star
1891 *
1892 - p) / p);
1893  return u
1894 *
1895 - a std::sqrt(1.0 + factor tmp);
1896  }
1897 *
1898  @endcode
1899 *
1900 * Analougously @cite GuermondPopov2016 Eqn. (3.8):
1901 
1902 *
1903 * @f{align*}
1904  \lambda^+ = u + a\,\sqrt{1 + \frac{\gamma+1}{2\gamma}
1905  \left(\frac{p^\ast-p}{p}\right)_+}
1906  @f}
1907 *
1908 *
1909 
1910 *
1911 *
1912 
1913 *
1914 * @code
1915  DEAL_II_ALWAYS_INLINE inline double
1916  lambda3_plus(const std::array<double, 4> &riemann_data, const double p_star)
1917  {
1918  /* Implements formula (3.8) in Guermond-Popov-2016 */
1919 *
1920  constexpr double gamma = ProblemDescription<1>::gamma;
1921  const auto u = riemann_data[1];
1922  const auto p = riemann_data[2];
1923  const auto a = riemann_data[3];
1924 *
1925  const double factor = (gamma + 1.0) / 2.0 / gamma;
1926  const double tmp = positive_part((p_star
1927 *
1928 - p) / p);
1929  return u + a std::sqrt(1.0 + factor tmp);
1930  }
1931 *
1932  @endcode
1933 *
1934 * All that is left to do is to compute the maximum of @f$\lambda^-@f$ and @f$\lambda^+@f$ computed from the left and right primitive state ( @cite GuermondPopov2016 Eqn. (2.11)), where @f$p^\ast@f$ is given by @cite GuermondPopov2016 Eqn (4.3):
1935 *
1936 
1937 *
1938 *
1939 
1940 *
1941 * @code
1942  DEAL_II_ALWAYS_INLINE inline double
1943  lambda_max_two_rarefaction(const std::array<double, 4> &riemann_data_i,
1944  const std::array<double, 4> &riemann_data_j)
1945  {
1946  constexpr double gamma = ProblemDescription<1>::gamma;
1947  const auto u_i = riemann_data_i[1];
1948  const auto p_i = riemann_data_i[2];
1949  const auto a_i = riemann_data_i[3];
1950  const auto u_j = riemann_data_j[1];
1951  const auto p_j = riemann_data_j[2];
1952  const auto a_j = riemann_data_j[3];
1953 *
1954  const double numerator = a_i + a_j
1955 *
1956 - (gamma
1957 *
1958 - 1.) / 2. (u_j
1959 *
1960 - u_i);
1961 *
1962  const double denominator =
1963  a_i std::pow(p_i / p_j,
1964 *
1965 -1. (gamma
1966 *
1967 - 1.) / 2. / gamma) + a_j 1.;
1968 *
1969  /* Formula (4.3) in Guermond-Popov-2016 */
1970 *
1971  const double p_star =
1972  p_j std::pow(numerator / denominator, 2. gamma / (gamma
1973 *
1974 - 1));
1975 *
1976  const double lambda1 = lambda1_minus(riemann_data_i, p_star);
1977  const double lambda3 = lambda3_plus(riemann_data_j, p_star);
1978 *
1979  /* Formula (2.11) in Guermond-Popov-2016 */
1980 *
1981  return std::max(positive_part(lambda3), negative_part(lambda1));
1982  }
1983 *
1984  @endcode
1985 *
1986 * We compute the second upper bound of the maximal wavespeed that is, in general, not as sharp as the two-rarefaction estimate. But it will save the day in the context of near vacuum conditions when the two-rarefaction approximation might attain extreme values:
1987 
1988 *
1989 * @f{align*}
1990  \lambda_{\text{exp}} = \max(u_i,u_j) + 5. \max(a_i, a_j).
1991  @f}
1992 *
1993 
1994 *
1995 * @note The constant 5.0 multiplying the maximum of the sound speeds is <i>neither</i> an ad-hoc constant, <i>nor</i> a tuning parameter. It defines an upper bound for any @f$\gamma \in [0,5/3]@f$ . Do not play with it!
1996 *
1997 
1998 *
1999 *
2000 
2001 *
2002 * @code
2003  DEAL_II_ALWAYS_INLINE inline double
2004  lambda_max_expansion(const std::array<double, 4> &riemann_data_i,
2005  const std::array<double, 4> &riemann_data_j)
2006  {
2007  const auto u_i = riemann_data_i[1];
2008  const auto a_i = riemann_data_i[3];
2009  const auto u_j = riemann_data_j[1];
2010  const auto a_j = riemann_data_j[3];
2011 *
2012  return std::max(std::abs(u_i), std::abs(u_j)) + 5. std::max(a_i, a_j);
2013  }
2014  } // namespace
2015 *
2016  @endcode
2017 *
2018 * The following is the main function that we are going to call in order to compute @f$\lambda_{\text{max}} (\mathbf{U}_i^{n},\mathbf{U}_j^{n},
2019  \textbf{n}_{ij})@f$ . We simply compute both maximal wavespeed estimates and return the minimum.
2020 *
2021 
2022 *
2023 *
2024 
2025 *
2026 * @code
2027  template <int dim>
2028  DEAL_II_ALWAYS_INLINE inline double
2029  ProblemDescription<dim>::compute_lambda_max(const state_type & U_i,
2030  const state_type & U_j,
2031  const Tensor<1, dim> &n_ij)
2032  {
2033  const auto riemann_data_i = riemann_data_from_state(U_i, n_ij);
2034  const auto riemann_data_j = riemann_data_from_state(U_j, n_ij);
2035 *
2036  const double lambda_1 =
2037  lambda_max_two_rarefaction(riemann_data_i, riemann_data_j);
2038 *
2039  const double lambda_2 =
2040  lambda_max_expansion(riemann_data_i, riemann_data_j);
2041 *
2042  return std::min(lambda_1, lambda_2);
2043  }
2044 *
2045  @endcode
2046 *
2047 * We conclude this section by defining static arrays <code>component_names</code> that contain strings describing the component names of our state vector. We have template specializations for dimensions one, two and three, that are used later in DataOut for naming the corresponding components:
2048 *
2049 
2050 *
2051 *
2052 
2053 *
2054 * @code
2055  template <>
2056  const std::array<std::string, 3> ProblemDescription<1>::component_names{
2057  {"rho", "m", "E"}};
2058 *
2059  template <>
2060  const std::array<std::string, 4> ProblemDescription<2>::component_names{
2061  {"rho", "m_1", "m_2", "E"}};
2062 *
2063  template <>
2064  const std::array<std::string, 5> ProblemDescription<3>::component_names{
2065  {"rho", "m_1", "m_2", "m_3", "E"}};
2066 *
2067  @endcode
2068 *
2069 * <a name="Initialvalues"></a> <h4>Initial values</h4>
2070 *
2071 
2072 *
2073 * The last preparatory step, before we discuss the implementation of the forward Euler scheme, is to briefly implement the `InitialValues` class.
2074 * In the constructor we initialize all parameters with default values, declare all parameters for the `ParameterAcceptor` class and connect the <code>parse_parameters_call_back</code> slot to the respective signal.
2075 * The <code>parse_parameters_call_back</code> slot will be invoked from ParameterAceptor after the call to ParameterAcceptor::initialize(). In that regard, its use is appropriate for situations where the parameters have to be postprocessed (in some sense) or some consistency condition between the parameters has to be checked.
2076 *
2077 
2078 *
2079 *
2080 
2081 *
2082 * @code
2083  template <int dim>
2084  InitialValues<dim>::InitialValues(const std::string &subsection)
2085  : ParameterAcceptor(subsection)
2086  {
2087  /* We wire up the slot InitialValues<dim>::parse_parameters_callback to
2088  the ParameterAcceptor::parse_parameters_call_back signal:
2089 *
2090  We wire up the slot InitialValues<dim>::parse_parameters_callback to
2091  the ParameterAcceptor::parse_parameters_call_back signal:/
2092  ParameterAcceptor::parse_parameters_call_back.connect(
2093  std::bind(&InitialValues<dim>::parse_parameters_callback, this));
2094 *
2095  initial_direction[0] = 1.;
2096  add_parameter("initial direction",
2097  initial_direction,
2098  "Initial direction of the uniform flow field");
2099 *
2100  initial_1d_state[0] = ProblemDescription<dim>::gamma;
2101  initial_1d_state[1] = 3.;
2102  initial_1d_state[2] = 1.;
2103  add_parameter("initial 1d state",
2104  initial_1d_state,
2105  "Initial 1d state (rho, u, p) of the uniform flow field");
2106  }
2107 *
2108  @endcode
2109 *
2110 * So far the constructor of <code>InitialValues</code> has defined default values for the two private members <code>initial_direction</code> and <code>initial_1d_state</code> and added them to the parameter list. But we have not defined an implementation of the only public member that we really care about, which is <code>initial_state()</code> (the function that we are going to call to actually evaluate the initial solution at the mesh nodes). At the top of the function, we have to ensure that the provided initial direction is not the zero vector.
2111 *
2112 
2113 *
2114 * @note As commented, we could have avoided using the method <code>parse_parameters_call_back </code> and defined a class member <code>setup()</code> in order to define the implementation of <code>initial_state()</code> . But for illustrative purposes we want to document a different way here and use the call back signal from ParameterAcceptor.
2115 *
2116 
2117 *
2118 *
2119 
2120 *
2121 * @code
2122  template <int dim>
2123  void InitialValues<dim>::parse_parameters_callback()
2124  {
2125  AssertThrow(initial_direction.norm() != 0.,
2126  ExcMessage(
2127  "Initial shock front direction is set to the zero vector."));
2128  initial_direction /= initial_direction.norm();
2129 *
2130  @endcode
2131 *
2132 * Next, we implement the <code>initial_state</code> function object with a lambda function computing a uniform flow field. For this we have to translate a given primitive 1d state (density @f$\rho@f$ , velocity @f$u@f$ , and pressure @f$p@f$ ) into a conserved n-dimensional state (density @f$\rho@f$ , momentum @f$\mathbf{m}@f$ , and total energy @f$E@f$ ).
2133 *
2134 
2135 *
2136 *
2137 
2138 *
2139 * @code
2140  initial_state = [this](const Point<dim> & /*point*/, double /*t*/ ) {
2141  const double rho = initial_1d_state[0];
2142  const double u = initial_1d_state[1];
2143  const double p = initial_1d_state[2];
2144  static constexpr double gamma = ProblemDescription<dim>::gamma;
2145 *
2146  state_type state;
2147 *
2148  state[0] = rho;
2149  for (unsigned int i = 0; i < dim; ++i)
2150  state[1 + i] = rho u initial_direction[i];
2151 *
2152  state[dim + 1] = p / (gamma
2153 *
2154 - 1.) + 0.5 rho u u;
2155 *
2156  return state;
2157  };
2158  }
2159 *
2160  @endcode
2161 *
2162 * <a name="TheForwardEulerstep"></a> <h4>The Forward Euler step</h4>
2163 *
2164 
2165 *
2166 * The constructor of the <code>%TimeStepping</code> class does not contain any surprising code:
2167 *
2168 
2169 *
2170 *
2171 
2172 *
2173 * @code
2174  template <int dim>
2175  TimeStepping<dim>::TimeStepping(
2176  const MPI_Comm mpi_communicator,
2177  TimerOutput & computing_timer,
2178  const OfflineData<dim> & offline_data,
2179  const InitialValues<dim> &initial_values,
2180  const std::string & subsection /*= "TimeStepping"*/ )
2181  : ParameterAcceptor(subsection)
2182  , mpi_communicator(mpi_communicator)
2183  , computing_timer(computing_timer)
2184  , offline_data(&offline_data)
2185  , initial_values(&initial_values)
2186  {
2187  cfl_update = 0.80;
2188  add_parameter("cfl update",
2189  cfl_update,
2190  "Relative CFL constant used for update");
2191  }
2192 *
2193  @endcode
2194 *
2195 * In the class member <code>prepare()</code> we initialize the temporary vector <code>temp</code> and the matrix <code>dij_matrix</code> . The vector <code>temp</code> will be used to store the solution update temporarily before its contents is swapped with the old vector.
2196 *
2197 
2198 *
2199 *
2200 
2201 *
2202 * @code
2203  template <int dim>
2204  void TimeStepping<dim>::prepare()
2205  {
2206  TimerOutput::Scope scope(computing_timer,
2207  "time_stepping
2208 *
2209 - prepare scratch space");
2210 *
2211  for (auto &it : temporary_vector)
2212  it.reinit(offline_data->partitioner);
2213 *
2214  dij_matrix.reinit(offline_data->sparsity_pattern);
2215  }
2216 *
2217  @endcode
2218 *
2219 * It is now time to implement the forward Euler step. Given a (writable reference) to the old state <code>U</code> at time @f$t@f$ we update the state <code>U</code> in place and return the chosen time-step size. We first declare a number of read-only references to various different variables and data structures. We do this is mainly to have shorter variable names (e.g., <code>sparsity</code> instead of <code>offline_data->sparsity_pattern</code> ).
2220 *
2221 
2222 *
2223 *
2224 
2225 *
2226 * @code
2227  template <int dim>
2228  double TimeStepping<dim>::make_one_step(vector_type &U, double t)
2229  {
2230  const auto &n_locally_owned = offline_data->n_locally_owned;
2231  const auto &n_locally_relevant = offline_data->n_locally_relevant;
2232 *
2233  const std_cxx20::ranges::iota_view<unsigned int, unsigned int>
2234  indices_owned(0, n_locally_owned);
2235  const std_cxx20::ranges::iota_view<unsigned int, unsigned int>
2236  indices_relevant(0, n_locally_relevant);
2237 *
2238  const auto &sparsity = offline_data->sparsity_pattern;
2239 *
2240  const auto &lumped_mass_matrix = offline_data->lumped_mass_matrix;
2241  const auto &norm_matrix = offline_data->norm_matrix;
2242  const auto &nij_matrix = offline_data->nij_matrix;
2243  const auto &cij_matrix = offline_data->cij_matrix;
2244 *
2245  const auto &boundary_normal_map = offline_data->boundary_normal_map;
2246 *
2247  @endcode
2248 *
2249 * <b>Step 1</b>: Computing the @f$d_{ij}@f$ graph viscosity matrix.
2250 * It is important to highlight that the viscosity matrix has to be symmetric, i.e., @f$d_{ij} = d_{ji}@f$ . In this regard we note here that @f$\int_{\Omega} \nabla \phi_j \phi_i \, \mathrm{d}\mathbf{x}=
2251 *
2252 -
2253  \int_{\Omega} \nabla \phi_i \phi_j \, \mathrm{d}\mathbf{x}@f$ (or equivalently @f$\mathbf{c}_{ij} =
2254 *
2255 - \mathbf{c}_{ji}@f$ ) provided either @f$\mathbf{x}_i@f$ or @f$\mathbf{x}_j@f$ is a support point located away from the boundary. In this case we can check that @f$\lambda_{\text{max}} (\mathbf{U}_i^{n}, \mathbf{U}_j^{n},
2256  \textbf{n}_{ij}) = \lambda_{\text{max}} (\mathbf{U}_j^{n},
2257  \mathbf{U}_i^{n},\textbf{n}_{ji})@f$ by construction, which guarantees the property @f$d_{ij} = d_{ji}@f$ .
2258 * However, if both support points @f$\mathbf{x}_i@f$ or @f$\mathbf{x}_j@f$ happen to lie on the boundary, then, the equalities @f$\mathbf{c}_{ij} =
2259 *
2260 
2261 
2262 *
2263 *
2264 - \mathbf{c}_{ji}@f$ and @f$\lambda_{\text{max}} (\mathbf{U}_i^{n},
2265  \mathbf{U}_j^{n}, \textbf{n}_{ij}) = \lambda_{\text{max}}
2266  (\mathbf{U}_j^{n}, \mathbf{U}_i^{n}, \textbf{n}_{ji})@f$ do not necessarily hold true. The only mathematically safe solution for this dilemma is to compute both of them @f$d_{ij}@f$ and @f$d_{ji}@f$ and take the maximum.
2267 * Overall, the computation of @f$d_{ij}@f$ is quite expensive. In order to save some computing time we exploit the fact that the viscosity matrix has to be symmetric (as mentioned above): we only compute the upper-triangular entries of @f$d_{ij}@f$ and copy the corresponding entries to the lower-triangular counterpart.
2268 * We use again parallel::apply_to_subranges() for thread-parallel for loops. Pretty much all the ideas for parallel traversal that we introduced when discussing the assembly of the matrix <code>norm_matrix</code> and the normalization of <code>nij_matrix</code> above are used here again.
2269 * We define again a "worker" function <code>on_subranges</code> that computes the viscosity @f$d_{ij}@f$ for a subrange [i1, i2) of column indices:
2270 *
2271 
2272 *
2273 * @code
2274  {
2275  TimerOutput::Scope scope(computing_timer,
2276  "time_stepping
2277 *
2278 - 1 compute d_ij");
2279 *
2280  const auto on_subranges =
2281  [&](const auto i1, const auto i2) {
2282  for (const auto i :
2283  std_cxx20::ranges::iota_view<unsigned int, unsigned int>(*i1,
2284  i2))
2285  {
2286  const auto U_i = gather(U, i);
2287 *
2288  @endcode
2289 *
2290 * For a given column index i we iterate over the columns of the sparsity pattern from <code>sparsity.begin(i)</code> to <code>sparsity.end(i)</code> :
2291 *
2292 
2293 *
2294 * @code
2295  for (auto jt = sparsity.begin(i); jt != sparsity.end(i); ++jt)
2296  {
2297  const auto j = jt->column();
2298 *
2299  @endcode
2300 *
2301 * We only compute @f$d_{ij}@f$ if @f$j < i@f$ (upper triangular entries) and later copy the values over to @f$d_{ji}@f$ .
2302 *
2303 
2304 *
2305 * @code
2306  if (j >= i)
2307  continue;
2308 *
2309  const auto U_j = gather(U, j);
2310 *
2311  const auto n_ij = gather_get_entry(nij_matrix, jt);
2312  const double norm = get_entry(norm_matrix, jt);
2313 *
2314  const auto lambda_max =
2315  ProblemDescription<dim>::compute_lambda_max(U_i, U_j, n_ij);
2316 *
2317  double d = norm lambda_max;
2318 *
2319  @endcode
2320 *
2321 * If both support points happen to be at the boundary we have to compute @f$d_{ji}@f$ as well and then take @f$\max(d_{ij},d_{ji})@f$ . After this we can finally set the upper triangular and lower triangular entries.
2322 *
2323 
2324 *
2325 * @code
2326  if (boundary_normal_map.count(i) != 0 &&
2327  boundary_normal_map.count(j) != 0)
2328  {
2329  const auto n_ji = gather(nij_matrix, j, i);
2330  const auto lambda_max_2 =
2331  ProblemDescription<dim>::compute_lambda_max(U_j,
2332  U_i,
2333  n_ji);
2334  const double norm_2 = norm_matrix(j, i);
2335 *
2336  d = std::max(d, norm_2 lambda_max_2);
2337  }
2338 *
2339  set_entry(dij_matrix, jt, d);
2340  dij_matrix(j, i) = d;
2341  }
2342  }
2343  };
2344 *
2345  parallel::apply_to_subranges(indices_relevant.begin(),
2346  indices_relevant.end(),
2347  on_subranges,
2348  4096);
2349  }
2350 *
2351  @endcode
2352 *
2353 * <b>Step 2</b>: Compute diagonal entries @f$d_{ii}@f$ and @f$\tau_{\text{max}}@f$ .
2354 *
2355 
2356 *
2357 * So far we have computed all off-diagonal entries of the matrix <code>dij_matrix</code> . We still have to fill its diagonal entries defined as @f$d_{ii}^n =
2358 *
2359 - \sum_{j \in \mathcal{I}(i)\backslash \{i\}}
2360  d_{ij}^n@f$ . We use again parallel::apply_to_subranges() for this purpose. While computing the @f$d_{ii}@f$ s we also determine the largest admissible time-step, which is defined as \f[
2361  \tau_n \dealcoloneq c_{\text{cfl}}\,\min_{i\in\mathcal{V}}
2362  \left(\frac{m_i}{-2\,d_{ii}^{n}}\right) \, .
2363  \f] Note that the operation @f$\min_{i \in \mathcal{V}}@f$ is intrinsically global, it operates on all nodes: first we have to take the minimum over all threads (of a given node) and then we have to take the minimum over all MPI processes. In the current implementation:
2364 *
2365 
2366 *
2367 *
2368 * - We store <code>tau_max</code> (per node) as <a
2369  href="http://www.cplusplus.com/reference/atomic/atomic/"><code>std::atomic<double></code></a>. The internal implementation of <code>std::atomic</code> will take care of guarding any possible race condition when more than one thread attempts to read and/or write <code>tau_max</code> at the same time.
2370 *
2371 
2372 *
2373 *
2374 * - In order to take the minimum over all MPI process we use the utility function <code>Utilities::MPI::min</code> .
2375 *
2376 
2377 *
2378 *
2379 
2380 *
2381 * @code
2382  std::atomic<double> tau_max{std::numeric_limits<double>::infinity()};
2383 *
2384  {
2385  TimerOutput::Scope scope(computing_timer,
2386  "time_stepping
2387 *
2388 - 2 compute d_ii, and tau_max");
2389 *
2390  @endcode
2391 *
2392 * on_subranges() will be executed on every thread individually. The variable <code>tau_max_on_subrange</code> is thus stored thread locally.
2393 *
2394 
2395 *
2396 *
2397 
2398 *
2399 * @code
2400  const auto on_subranges =
2401  [&](const auto i1, const auto i2) {
2402  double tau_max_on_subrange = std::numeric_limits<double>::infinity();
2403 *
2404  for (const auto i :
2405  std_cxx20::ranges::iota_view<unsigned int, unsigned int>(*i1,
2406  i2))
2407  {
2408  double d_sum = 0.;
2409 *
2410  for (auto jt = sparsity.begin(i); jt != sparsity.end(i); ++jt)
2411  {
2412  const auto j = jt->column();
2413 *
2414  if (j == i)
2415  continue;
2416 *
2417  d_sum
2418 *
2419 -= get_entry(dij_matrix, jt);
2420  }
2421 *
2422  @endcode
2423 *
2424 * We store the negative sum of the d_ij entries at the diagonal position
2425 *
2426 
2427 *
2428 * @code
2429  dij_matrix.diag_element(i) = d_sum;
2430  @endcode
2431 *
2432 * and compute the maximal local time-step size <code>tau</code> :
2433 *
2434 
2435 *
2436 * @code
2437  const double mass = lumped_mass_matrix.diag_element(i);
2438  const double tau = cfl_update mass / (-2. d_sum);
2439  tau_max_on_subrange = std::min(tau_max_on_subrange, tau);
2440  }
2441 *
2442  @endcode
2443 *
2444 * <code>tau_max_on_subrange</code> contains the largest possible time-step size computed for the (thread local) subrange. At this point we have to synchronize the value over all threads. This is were we use the <a
2445  href="http://www.cplusplus.com/reference/atomic/atomic/"><code>std::atomic<double></code></a> <i>compare exchange</i> update mechanism:
2446 *
2447 
2448 *
2449 * @code
2450  double current_tau_max = tau_max.load();
2451  while (current_tau_max > tau_max_on_subrange &&
2452  !tau_max.compare_exchange_weak(current_tau_max,
2453  tau_max_on_subrange))
2454  ;
2455  };
2456 *
2457  parallel::apply_to_subranges(indices_relevant.begin(),
2458  indices_relevant.end(),
2459  on_subranges,
2460  4096);
2461 *
2462  @endcode
2463 *
2464 * After all threads have finished we can simply synchronize the value over all MPI processes:
2465 *
2466 
2467 *
2468 *
2469 
2470 *
2471 * @code
2472  tau_max.store(Utilities::MPI::min(tau_max.load(), mpi_communicator));
2473 *
2474  @endcode
2475 *
2476 * This is a good point to verify that the computed <code>tau_max</code> is indeed a valid floating point number.
2477 *
2478 
2479 *
2480 * @code
2481  AssertThrow(
2482  !std::isnan(tau_max.load()) && !std::isinf(tau_max.load()) &&
2483  tau_max.load() > 0.,
2484  ExcMessage(
2485  "I'm sorry, Dave. I'm afraid I can't do that.
2486 *
2487 - We crashed."));
2488  }
2489 *
2490  @endcode
2491 *
2492 * <b>Step 3</b>: Perform update.
2493 *
2494 
2495 *
2496 * At this point, we have computed all viscosity coefficients @f$d_{ij}@f$ and we know the maximal admissible time-step size @f$\tau_{\text{max}}@f$ . This means we can now compute the update:
2497 * \f[
2498  \mathbf{U}_i^{n+1} = \mathbf{U}_i^{n}
2499 *
2500 - \frac{\tau_{\text{max}} }{m_i}
2501  \sum_{j \in \mathcal{I}(i)} (\mathbb{f}(\mathbf{U}_j^{n})
2502 *
2503 -
2504  \mathbb{f}(\mathbf{U}_i^{n})) \cdot \mathbf{c}_{ij}
2505 *
2506 - d_{ij}
2507  (\mathbf{U}_j^{n}
2508 *
2509 - \mathbf{U}_i^{n})
2510  \f]
2511 * This update formula is slightly different from what was discussed in the introduction (in the pseudo-code). However, it can be shown that both equations are algebraically equivalent (they will produce the same numerical values). We favor this second formula since it has natural cancellation properties that might help avoid numerical artifacts.
2512 *
2513 
2514 *
2515 *
2516 
2517 *
2518 * @code
2519  {
2520  TimerOutput::Scope scope(computing_timer,
2521  "time_stepping
2522 *
2523 - 3 perform update");
2524 *
2525  const auto on_subranges =
2526  [&](const auto i1, const auto i2) {
2527  for (const auto i : boost::make_iterator_range(i1, i2))
2528  {
2529  Assert(i < n_locally_owned, ExcInternalError());
2530 *
2531  const auto U_i = gather(U, i);
2532 *
2533  const auto f_i = ProblemDescription<dim>::flux(U_i);
2534  const double m_i = lumped_mass_matrix.diag_element(i);
2535 *
2536  auto U_i_new = U_i;
2537 *
2538  for (auto jt = sparsity.begin(i); jt != sparsity.end(i); ++jt)
2539  {
2540  const auto j = jt->column();
2541 *
2542  const auto U_j = gather(U, j);
2543  const auto f_j = ProblemDescription<dim>::flux(U_j);
2544 *
2545  const auto c_ij = gather_get_entry(cij_matrix, jt);
2546  const auto d_ij = get_entry(dij_matrix, jt);
2547 *
2548  for (unsigned int k = 0; k < problem_dimension; ++k)
2549  {
2550  U_i_new[k] +=
2551  tau_max / m_i
2552  (-(f_j[k]
2553 *
2554 - f_i[k]) c_ij + d_ij (U_j[k]
2555 *
2556 - U_i[k]));
2557  }
2558  }
2559 *
2560  scatter(temporary_vector, U_i_new, i);
2561  }
2562  };
2563 *
2564  parallel::apply_to_subranges(indices_owned.begin(),
2565  indices_owned.end(),
2566  on_subranges,
2567  4096);
2568  }
2569 *
2570  @endcode
2571 *
2572 * <b>Step 4</b>: Fix up boundary states.
2573 *
2574 
2575 *
2576 * As a last step in the Forward Euler method, we have to fix up all boundary states. As discussed in the intro we
2577 *
2578 
2579 *
2580 *
2581 * - advance in time satisfying no boundary condition at all,
2582 *
2583 
2584 *
2585 *
2586 * - at the end of the time step enforce boundary conditions strongly in a post-processing step.
2587 * Here, we compute the correction \f[
2588  \mathbf{m}_i \dealcoloneq \mathbf{m}_i
2589 *
2590 - (\boldsymbol{\nu}_i \cdot
2591  \mathbf{m}_i) \boldsymbol{\nu}_i,
2592  \f] which removes the normal component of @f$\mathbf{m}@f$ .
2593 *
2594 
2595 *
2596 *
2597 
2598 *
2599 * @code
2600  {
2601  TimerOutput::Scope scope(computing_timer,
2602  "time_stepping
2603 *
2604 - 4 fix boundary states");
2605 *
2606  for (auto it : boundary_normal_map)
2607  {
2608  const auto i = it.first;
2609 *
2610  @endcode
2611 *
2612 * We only iterate over the locally owned subset:
2613 *
2614 
2615 *
2616 * @code
2617  if (i >= n_locally_owned)
2618  continue;
2619 *
2620  const auto &normal = std::get<0>(it.second);
2621  const auto &id = std::get<1>(it.second);
2622  const auto &position = std::get<2>(it.second);
2623 *
2624  auto U_i = gather(temporary_vector, i);
2625 *
2626  @endcode
2627 *
2628 * On free slip boundaries we remove the normal component of the momentum:
2629 *
2630 
2631 *
2632 * @code
2633  if (id == Boundaries::free_slip)
2634  {
2635  auto m = ProblemDescription<dim>::momentum(U_i);
2636  m
2637 *
2638 -= (m normal) normal;
2639  for (unsigned int k = 0; k < dim; ++k)
2640  U_i[k + 1] = m[k];
2641  }
2642 *
2643  @endcode
2644 *
2645 * On Dirichlet boundaries we enforce initial conditions strongly:
2646 *
2647 
2648 *
2649 * @code
2650  else if (id == Boundaries::dirichlet)
2651  {
2652  U_i = initial_values->initial_state(position, t + tau_max);
2653  }
2654 *
2655  scatter(temporary_vector, U_i, i);
2656  }
2657  }
2658 *
2659  @endcode
2660 *
2661 * <b>Step 5</b>: We now update the ghost layer over all MPI ranks, swap the temporary vector with the solution vector <code>U</code> (that will get returned by reference) and return the chosen time-step size @f$\tau_{\text{max}}@f$ :
2662 *
2663 
2664 *
2665 *
2666 
2667 *
2668 * @code
2669  for (auto &it : temporary_vector)
2670  it.update_ghost_values();
2671 *
2672  U.swap(temporary_vector);
2673 *
2674  return tau_max;
2675  }
2676 *
2677  @endcode
2678 *
2679 * <a name="Schlierenpostprocessing"></a> <h4>Schlieren postprocessing</h4>
2680 * At various intervals we will output the current state <code>U</code> of the solution together with a so-called Schlieren plot. The constructor of the <code>SchlierenPostprocessor</code> class again contains no surprises. We simply supply default values to and register two parameters:
2681 *
2682 
2683 *
2684 *
2685 * - schlieren_beta: is an ad-hoc positive amplification factor in order to enhance the contrast in the visualization. Its actual value is a matter of taste.
2686 *
2687 
2688 *
2689 *
2690 * - schlieren_index: is an integer indicating which component of the state @f$[\rho, \mathbf{m},E]@f$ are we going to use in order to generate the visualization.
2691 *
2692 
2693 *
2694 *
2695 
2696 *
2697 * @code
2698  template <int dim>
2699  SchlierenPostprocessor<dim>::SchlierenPostprocessor(
2700  const MPI_Comm mpi_communicator,
2701  TimerOutput & computing_timer,
2702  const OfflineData<dim> &offline_data,
2703  const std::string & subsection /*= "SchlierenPostprocessor"*/ )
2704  : ParameterAcceptor(subsection)
2705  , mpi_communicator(mpi_communicator)
2706  , computing_timer(computing_timer)
2707  , offline_data(&offline_data)
2708  {
2709  schlieren_beta = 10.;
2710  add_parameter("schlieren beta",
2711  schlieren_beta,
2712  "Beta factor used in Schlieren-type postprocessor");
2713 *
2714  schlieren_index = 0;
2715  add_parameter("schlieren index",
2716  schlieren_index,
2717  "Use the corresponding component of the state vector for the "
2718  "schlieren plot");
2719  }
2720 *
2721  @endcode
2722 *
2723 * Again, the <code>prepare()</code> function initializes two temporary the vectors ( <code>r</code> and <code>schlieren</code> ).
2724 *
2725 
2726 *
2727 *
2728 
2729 *
2730 * @code
2731  template <int dim>
2732  void SchlierenPostprocessor<dim>::prepare()
2733  {
2734  TimerOutput::Scope scope(computing_timer,
2735  "schlieren_postprocessor
2736 *
2737 - prepare scratch space");
2738 *
2739  r.reinit(offline_data->n_locally_relevant);
2740  schlieren.reinit(offline_data->partitioner);
2741  }
2742 *
2743  @endcode
2744 *
2745 * We now discuss the implementation of the class member <code>SchlierenPostprocessor<dim>::compute_schlieren()</code> , which basically takes a component of the state vector <code>U</code> and computes the Schlieren indicator for such component (the formula of the Schlieren indicator can be found just before the declaration of the class <code>SchlierenPostprocessor</code> ). We start by noting that this formula requires the "nodal gradients" @f$\nabla r_j@f$ . However, nodal values of gradients are not defined for @f$\mathcal{C}^0@f$ finite element functions. More generally, pointwise values of gradients are not defined for @f$W^{1,p}(\Omega)@f$ functions. The simplest technique we can use to recover gradients at nodes is weighted-averaging i.e.
2746 * \f[ \nabla r_j \dealcoloneq \frac{1}{\int_{S_i} \omega_i(\mathbf{x}) \,
2747  \mathrm{d}\mathbf{x}}
2748  \int_{S_i} r_h(\mathbf{x}) \omega_i(\mathbf{x}) \, \mathrm{d}\mathbf{x}
2749  \ \ \ \ \ \mathbf{(*)} \f]
2750 * where @f$S_i@f$ is the support of the shape function @f$\phi_i@f$ , and @f$\omega_i(\mathbf{x})@f$ is the weight. The weight could be any positive function such as @f$\omega_i(\mathbf{x}) \equiv 1@f$ (that would allow us to recover the usual notion of mean value). But as usual, the goal is to reuse the off-line data as much as possible. In this sense, the most natural choice of weight is @f$\omega_i = \phi_i@f$ . Inserting this choice of weight and the expansion @f$r_h(\mathbf{x}) = \sum_{j \in \mathcal{V}}
2751  r_j \phi_j(\mathbf{x})@f$ into @f$\mathbf{(*)}@f$ we get :
2752 * \f[ \nabla r_j \dealcoloneq \frac{1}{m_i} \sum_{j \in \mathcal{I}(i)} r_j
2753  \mathbf{c}_{ij} \ \ \ \ \ \mathbf{(**)} \, . \f]
2754 * Using this last formula we can recover averaged nodal gradients without resorting to any form of quadrature. This idea aligns quite well with the whole spirit of edge-based schemes (or algebraic schemes) where we want to operate on matrices and vectors as directly as it could be possible avoiding by all means assembly of bilinear forms, cell-loops, quadrature, or any other intermediate construct/operation between the input arguments (the state from the previous time-step) and the actual matrices and vectors required to compute the update.
2755 * The second thing to note is that we have to compute global minimum and maximum @f$\max_j |\nabla r_j|@f$ and @f$\min_j |\nabla r_j|@f$ . Following the same ideas used to compute the time step size in the class member <code>%TimeStepping\<dim>::%step()</code> we define @f$\max_j |\nabla r_j|@f$ and @f$\min_j |\nabla r_j|@f$ as atomic doubles in order to resolve any conflicts between threads. As usual, we use <code>Utilities::MPI::max()</code> and <code>Utilities::MPI::min()</code> to find the global maximum/minimum among all MPI processes.
2756 * Finally, it is not possible to compute the Schlieren indicator in a single loop over all nodes. The entire operation requires two loops over nodes:
2757 *
2758 
2759 *
2760 *
2761 
2762 *
2763 *
2764 
2765 *
2766 *
2767 
2768 *
2769 *
2770 
2771 *
2772 *
2773 
2774 *
2775 *
2776 
2777 *
2778 *
2779 * - The first loop computes @f$|\nabla r_i|@f$ for all @f$i \in \mathcal{V}@f$ in the mesh, and the bounds @f$\max_j |\nabla r_j|@f$ and @f$\min_j |\nabla r_j|@f$ .
2780 *
2781 
2782 *
2783 *
2784 * - The second loop finally computes the Schlieren indicator using the formula
2785 * \f[ \text{schlieren}[i] = e^{\beta \frac{ |\nabla r_i|
2786 *
2787 
2788 
2789 *
2790 *
2791 - \min_j |\nabla r_j| }{\max_j |\nabla r_j|
2792 *
2793 - \min_j |\nabla r_j| } }
2794  \, . \f]
2795 * This means that we will have to define two workers <code>on_subranges</code> for each one of these stages.
2796 *
2797 
2798 *
2799 *
2800 
2801 *
2802 * @code
2803  template <int dim>
2804  void SchlierenPostprocessor<dim>::compute_schlieren(const vector_type &U)
2805  {
2806  TimerOutput::Scope scope(
2807  computing_timer, "schlieren_postprocessor
2808 *
2809 - compute schlieren plot");
2810 *
2811  const auto &sparsity = offline_data->sparsity_pattern;
2812  const auto &lumped_mass_matrix = offline_data->lumped_mass_matrix;
2813  const auto &cij_matrix = offline_data->cij_matrix;
2814  const auto &boundary_normal_map = offline_data->boundary_normal_map;
2815  const auto &n_locally_owned = offline_data->n_locally_owned;
2816 *
2817  const auto indices =
2818  std_cxx20::ranges::iota_view<unsigned int, unsigned int>(0,
2819  n_locally_owned);
2820 *
2821  @endcode
2822 *
2823 * We define the r_i_max and r_i_min in the current MPI process as atomic doubles in order to avoid race conditions between threads:
2824 *
2825 
2826 *
2827 * @code
2828  std::atomic<double> r_i_max{0.};
2829  std::atomic<double> r_i_min{std::numeric_limits<double>::infinity()};
2830 *
2831  @endcode
2832 *
2833 * First loop: compute the averaged gradient at each node and the global maxima and minima of the gradients.
2834 *
2835 
2836 *
2837 * @code
2838  {
2839  const auto on_subranges =
2840  [&](const auto i1, const auto i2) {
2841  double r_i_max_on_subrange = 0.;
2842  double r_i_min_on_subrange = std::numeric_limits<double>::infinity();
2843 *
2844  for (const auto i : boost::make_iterator_range(i1, i2))
2845  {
2846  Assert(i < n_locally_owned, ExcInternalError());
2847 *
2848  Tensor<1, dim> r_i;
2849 *
2850  for (auto jt = sparsity.begin(i); jt != sparsity.end(i); ++jt)
2851  {
2852  const auto j = jt->column();
2853 *
2854  if (i == j)
2855  continue;
2856 *
2857  const auto U_js = U[schlieren_index].local_element(j);
2858  const auto c_ij = gather_get_entry(cij_matrix, jt);
2859  r_i += c_ij U_js;
2860  }
2861 *
2862  @endcode
2863 *
2864 * We fix up the gradient r_i at free slip boundaries similarly to how we fixed up boundary states in the forward Euler step. This avoids sharp, artificial gradients in the Schlieren plot at free slip boundaries and is a purely cosmetic choice.
2865 *
2866 
2867 *
2868 *
2869 
2870 *
2871 * @code
2872  const auto bnm_it = boundary_normal_map.find(i);
2873  if (bnm_it != boundary_normal_map.end())
2874  {
2875  const auto &normal = std::get<0>(bnm_it->second);
2876  const auto &id = std::get<1>(bnm_it->second);
2877 *
2878  if (id == Boundaries::free_slip)
2879  r_i
2880 *
2881 -= 1. (r_i normal) normal;
2882  else
2883  r_i = 0.;
2884  }
2885 *
2886  @endcode
2887 *
2888 * We remind the reader that we are not interested in the nodal gradients per se. We only want their norms in order to compute the Schlieren indicator (weighted with the lumped mass matrix @f$m_i@f$ ):
2889 *
2890 
2891 *
2892 * @code
2893  const double m_i = lumped_mass_matrix.diag_element(i);
2894  r[i] = r_i.norm() / m_i;
2895  r_i_max_on_subrange = std::max(r_i_max_on_subrange, r[i]);
2896  r_i_min_on_subrange = std::min(r_i_min_on_subrange, r[i]);
2897  }
2898 *
2899  @endcode
2900 *
2901 * We compare the current_r_i_max and current_r_i_min (in the current subrange) with r_i_max and r_i_min (for the current MPI process) and update them if necessary:
2902 *
2903 
2904 *
2905 *
2906 
2907 *
2908 * @code
2909  double current_r_i_max = r_i_max.load();
2910  while (current_r_i_max < r_i_max_on_subrange &&
2911  !r_i_max.compare_exchange_weak(current_r_i_max,
2912  r_i_max_on_subrange))
2913  ;
2914 *
2915  double current_r_i_min = r_i_min.load();
2916  while (current_r_i_min > r_i_min_on_subrange &&
2917  !r_i_min.compare_exchange_weak(current_r_i_min,
2918  r_i_min_on_subrange))
2919  ;
2920  };
2921 *
2922  parallel::apply_to_subranges(indices.begin(),
2923  indices.end(),
2924  on_subranges,
2925  4096);
2926  }
2927 *
2928  @endcode
2929 *
2930 * And synchronize <code>r_i_max</code> and <code>r_i_min</code> over all MPI processes.
2931 *
2932 
2933 *
2934 *
2935 
2936 *
2937 * @code
2938  r_i_max.store(Utilities::MPI::max(r_i_max.load(), mpi_communicator));
2939  r_i_min.store(Utilities::MPI::min(r_i_min.load(), mpi_communicator));
2940 *
2941  @endcode
2942 *
2943 * Second loop: we now have the vector <code>r</code> and the scalars <code>r_i_max</code> and <code>r_i_min</code> at our disposal. We are thus in a position to actually compute the Schlieren indicator.
2944 *
2945 
2946 *
2947 *
2948 
2949 *
2950 * @code
2951  {
2952  const auto on_subranges =
2953  [&](const auto i1, const auto i2) {
2954  for (const auto i : boost::make_iterator_range(i1, i2))
2955  {
2956  Assert(i < n_locally_owned, ExcInternalError());
2957 *
2958  schlieren.local_element(i) =
2959  1.
2960 *
2961 - std::exp(-schlieren_beta (r[i]
2962 *
2963 - r_i_min) /
2964  (r_i_max
2965 *
2966 - r_i_min));
2967  }
2968  };
2969 *
2970  parallel::apply_to_subranges(indices.begin(),
2971  indices.end(),
2972  on_subranges,
2973  4096);
2974  }
2975 *
2976  @endcode
2977 *
2978 * And finally, exchange ghost elements.
2979 *
2980 
2981 *
2982 * @code
2983  schlieren.update_ghost_values();
2984  }
2985 *
2986  @endcode
2987 *
2988 * <a name="Themainloop"></a> <h4>The main loop</h4>
2989 * With all classes implemented it is time to create an instance of <code>Discretization<dim></code>, <code>OfflineData<dim></code> , <code>InitialValues<dim></code>, <code>%TimeStepping\<dim></code> , and <code>SchlierenPostprocessor<dim></code> , and run the forward Euler step in a loop.
2990 * In the constructor of <code>MainLoop<dim></code> we now initialize an instance of all classes, and declare a number of parameters controlling output. Most notable, we declare a boolean parameter <code>resume</code> that will control whether the program attempts to restart from an interrupted computation, or not.
2991 *
2992 
2993 *
2994 *
2995 
2996 *
2997 * @code
2998  template <int dim>
2999  MainLoop<dim>::MainLoop(const MPI_Comm mpi_communicator)
3000  : ParameterAcceptor("A
3001 *
3002 - MainLoop")
3003  , mpi_communicator(mpi_communicator)
3004  , computing_timer(mpi_communicator,
3005  timer_output,
3006  TimerOutput::never,
3007  TimerOutput::cpu_and_wall_times)
3008  , pcout(std::cout, Utilities::MPI::this_mpi_process(mpi_communicator) == 0)
3009  , discretization(mpi_communicator, computing_timer, "B
3010 *
3011 - Discretization")
3012  , offline_data(mpi_communicator,
3013  computing_timer,
3014  discretization,
3015  "C
3016 *
3017 - OfflineData")
3018  , initial_values("D
3019 *
3020 - InitialValues")
3021  , time_stepping(mpi_communicator,
3022  computing_timer,
3023  offline_data,
3024  initial_values,
3025  "E
3026 *
3027 - TimeStepping")
3028  , schlieren_postprocessor(mpi_communicator,
3029  computing_timer,
3030  offline_data,
3031  "F
3032 *
3033 - SchlierenPostprocessor")
3034  {
3035  base_name = "test";
3036  add_parameter("basename", base_name, "Base name for all output files");
3037 *
3038  t_final = 4.;
3039  add_parameter("final time", t_final, "Final time");
3040 *
3041  output_granularity = 0.02;
3042  add_parameter("output granularity",
3043  output_granularity,
3044  "time interval for output");
3045 *
3046  asynchronous_writeback = true;
3047  add_parameter("asynchronous writeback",
3048  asynchronous_writeback,
3049  "Write out solution in a background thread performing IO");
3050 *
3051  resume = false;
3052  add_parameter("resume", resume, "Resume an interrupted computation.");
3053  }
3054 *
3055  @endcode
3056 *
3057 * We start by implementing a helper function <code>print_head()</code> in an anonymous namespace that is used to output messages in the terminal with some nice formatting.
3058 *
3059 
3060 *
3061 *
3062 
3063 *
3064 * @code
3065  namespace
3066  {
3067  void print_head(ConditionalOStream &pcout,
3068  const std::string & header,
3069  const std::string & secondary = "")
3070  {
3071  const auto header_size = header.size();
3072  const auto padded_header = std::string((34
3073 *
3074 - header_size) / 2, ' ') +
3075  header +
3076  std::string((35
3077 *
3078 - header_size) / 2, ' ');
3079 *
3080  const auto secondary_size = secondary.size();
3081  const auto padded_secondary =
3082  std::string((34
3083 *
3084 - secondary_size) / 2, ' ') + secondary +
3085  std::string((35
3086 *
3087 - secondary_size) / 2, ' ');
3088 *
3089  /* clang-format off */
3090  pcout << std::endl;
3091  pcout << " ####################################################" << std::endl;
3092  pcout << " ######### #########" << std::endl;
3093  pcout << " #########" << padded_header << "#########" << std::endl;
3094  pcout << " #########" << padded_secondary << "#########" << std::endl;
3095  pcout << " ######### #########" << std::endl;
3096  pcout << " ####################################################" << std::endl;
3097  pcout << std::endl;
3098  /* clang-format on */
3099  }
3100  } // namespace
3101 *
3102  @endcode
3103 *
3104 * With <code>print_head</code> in place it is now time to implement the <code>MainLoop<dim>::run()</code> that contains the main loop of our program.
3105 *
3106 
3107 *
3108 *
3109 
3110 *
3111 * @code
3112  template <int dim>
3113  void MainLoop<dim>::run()
3114  {
3115  @endcode
3116 *
3117 * We start by reading in parameters and initializing all objects. We note here that the call to ParameterAcceptor::initialize reads in all parameters from the parameter file (whose name is given as a string argument). ParameterAcceptor handles a global ParameterHandler that is initialized with subsections and parameter declarations for all class instances that are derived from ParameterAceptor. The call to initialize enters the subsection for each each derived class, and sets all variables that were added using ParameterAcceptor::add_parameter()
3118 *
3119 
3120 *
3121 *
3122 
3123 *
3124 * @code
3125  pcout << "Reading parameters and allocating objects... " << std::flush;
3126 *
3127  ParameterAcceptor::initialize("step-69.prm");
3128  pcout << "done" << std::endl;
3129 *
3130  @endcode
3131 *
3132 * Next we create the triangulation, assemble all matrices, set up scratch space, and initialize the DataOut<dim> object:
3133 *
3134 
3135 *
3136 *
3137 
3138 *
3139 * @code
3140  {
3141  print_head(pcout, "create triangulation");
3142  discretization.setup();
3143 *
3144  pcout << "Number of active cells: "
3145  << discretization.triangulation.n_global_active_cells()
3146  << std::endl;
3147 *
3148  print_head(pcout, "compute offline data");
3149  offline_data.setup();
3150  offline_data.assemble();
3151 *
3152  pcout << "Number of degrees of freedom: "
3153  << offline_data.dof_handler.n_dofs() << std::endl;
3154 *
3155  print_head(pcout, "set up time step");
3156  time_stepping.prepare();
3157  schlieren_postprocessor.prepare();
3158  }
3159 *
3160  @endcode
3161 *
3162 * We will store the current time and state in the variable <code>t</code> and vector <code>U</code> :
3163 *
3164 
3165 *
3166 *
3167 
3168 *
3169 * @code
3170  double t = 0.;
3171  unsigned int output_cycle = 0;
3172 *
3173  print_head(pcout, "interpolate initial values");
3174  vector_type U = interpolate_initial_values();
3175 *
3176  @endcode
3177 *
3178 * <a name="Resume"></a> <h5>Resume</h5>
3179 * By default the boolean <code>resume</code> is set to false, i.e. the following code snippet is not run. However, if <code>resume==true</code> we indicate that we have indeed an interrupted computation and the program shall restart by reading in an old state consisting of <code>t</code> , <code>output_cycle</code>, and <code>U</code> from a checkpoint file. These checkpoint files will be created in the <code>output()</code> routine discussed below.
3180 *
3181 
3182 *
3183 *
3184 
3185 *
3186 * @code
3187  if (resume)
3188  {
3189  print_head(pcout, "restore interrupted computation");
3190 *
3191  const unsigned int i =
3192  discretization.triangulation.locally_owned_subdomain();
3193 *
3194  const std::string name = base_name + "-checkpoint-" +
3195  Utilities::int_to_string(i, 4) + ".archive";
3196  std::ifstream file(name, std::ios::binary);
3197 *
3198  @endcode
3199 *
3200 * We use a <code>boost::archive</code> to store and read in the contents the checkpointed state.
3201 *
3202 
3203 *
3204 *
3205 
3206 *
3207 * @code
3208  boost::archive::binary_iarchive ia(file);
3209  ia >> t >> output_cycle;
3210 *
3211  for (auto &it1 : U)
3212  {
3213  @endcode
3214 *
3215 * <code>it1</code> iterates over all components of the state vector <code>U</code> . We read in every entry of the component in sequence and update the ghost layer afterwards:
3216 *
3217 
3218 *
3219 * @code
3220  for (auto &it2 : it1)
3221  ia >> it2;
3222  it1.update_ghost_values();
3223  }
3224  }
3225 *
3226  @endcode
3227 *
3228 * With either the initial state set up, or an interrupted state restored it is time to enter the main loop:
3229 *
3230 
3231 *
3232 *
3233 
3234 *
3235 * @code
3236  output(U, base_name, t, output_cycle++);
3237 *
3238  print_head(pcout, "enter main loop");
3239 *
3240  for (unsigned int cycle = 1; t < t_final; ++cycle)
3241  {
3242  @endcode
3243 *
3244 * We first print an informative status message
3245 *
3246 
3247 *
3248 *
3249 
3250 *
3251 * @code
3252  std::ostringstream head;
3253  std::ostringstream secondary;
3254 *
3255  head << "Cycle " << Utilities::int_to_string(cycle, 6) << " ("
3256  << std::fixed << std::setprecision(1) << t / t_final 100
3257  << "%)";
3258  secondary << "at time t = " << std::setprecision(8) << std::fixed << t;
3259 *
3260  print_head(pcout, head.str(), secondary.str());
3261 *
3262  @endcode
3263 *
3264 * and then perform a single forward Euler step. Note that the state vector <code>U</code> is updated in place and that <code>time_stepping.make_one_step()</code> returns the chosen step size.
3265 *
3266 
3267 *
3268 *
3269 
3270 *
3271 * @code
3272  t += time_stepping.make_one_step(U, t);
3273 *
3274  @endcode
3275 *
3276 * Post processing, generating output and writing out the current state is a CPU and IO intensive task that we cannot afford to do every time step
3277 *
3278 * - in particular with explicit time stepping. We thus only schedule output by calling the <code>output()</code> function if we are past a threshold set by <code>output_granularity</code> .
3279 *
3280 
3281 *
3282 *
3283 
3284 *
3285 * @code
3286  if (t > output_cycle output_granularity)
3287  {
3288  output(U, base_name, t, output_cycle, true);
3289  ++output_cycle;
3290  }
3291  }
3292 *
3293  @endcode
3294 *
3295 * We wait for any remaining background output thread to finish before printing a summary and exiting.
3296 *
3297 
3298 *
3299 * @code
3300  if (background_thread_state.valid())
3301  background_thread_state.wait();
3302 *
3303  computing_timer.print_summary();
3304  pcout << timer_output.str() << std::endl;
3305  }
3306 *
3307  @endcode
3308 *
3309 * The <code>interpolate_initial_values</code> takes an initial time "t" as input argument and populates a state vector <code>U</code> with the help of the <code>InitialValues<dim>::initial_state</code> object.
3310 *
3311 
3312 *
3313 *
3314 
3315 *
3316 * @code
3317  template <int dim>
3318  typename MainLoop<dim>::vector_type
3319  MainLoop<dim>::interpolate_initial_values(const double t)
3320  {
3321  pcout << "MainLoop<dim>::interpolate_initial_values(t = " << t << ")"
3322  << std::endl;
3323  TimerOutput::Scope scope(computing_timer,
3324  "main_loop
3325 *
3326 - setup scratch space");
3327 *
3328  vector_type U;
3329 *
3330  for (auto &it : U)
3331  it.reinit(offline_data.partitioner);
3332 *
3333  constexpr auto problem_dimension =
3334  ProblemDescription<dim>::problem_dimension;
3335 *
3336  @endcode
3337 *
3338 * The function signature of <code>InitialValues<dim>::initial_state</code> is not quite right for VectorTools::interpolate(). We work around this issue by, first, creating a lambda function that for a given position <code>x</code> returns just the value of the <code>i</code> th component. This lambda in turn is converted to a ::Function with the help of the ScalarFunctionFromFunctionObject wrapper.
3339 *
3340 
3341 *
3342 *
3343 
3344 *
3345 * @code
3346  for (unsigned int i = 0; i < problem_dimension; ++i)
3347  VectorTools::interpolate(offline_data.dof_handler,
3348  ScalarFunctionFromFunctionObject<dim, double>(
3349  [&](const Point<dim> &x) {
3350  return initial_values.initial_state(x, t)[i];
3351  }),
3352  U[i]);
3353 *
3354  for (auto &it : U)
3355  it.update_ghost_values();
3356 *
3357  return U;
3358  }
3359 *
3360  @endcode
3361 *
3362 * <a name="Outputandcheckpointing"></a> <h5>Output and checkpointing</h5>
3363 * Writing out the final vtk files is quite an IO intensive task that can stall the main loop for a while. In order to avoid this we use an <a
3364  href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asynchronous_I/O">asynchronous
3365  IO</a> strategy by creating a background thread that will perform IO while the main loop is allowed to continue. In order for this to work we have to be mindful of two things:
3366 *
3367 
3368 *
3369 *
3370 * - Before running the <code>output_worker</code> thread, we have to create a copy of the state vector <code>U</code> . We store it in the vector <code>output_vector</code> .
3371 *
3372 
3373 *
3374 *
3375 * - We have to avoid any MPI communication in the background thread, otherwise the program might deadlock. This implies that we have to run the postprocessing outside of the worker thread.
3376 *
3377 
3378 *
3379 *
3380 
3381 *
3382 * @code
3383  template <int dim>
3384  void MainLoop<dim>::output(const typename MainLoop<dim>::vector_type &U,
3385  const std::string & name,
3386  const double t,
3387  const unsigned int cycle,
3388  const bool checkpoint)
3389  {
3390  pcout << "MainLoop<dim>::output(t = " << t
3391  << ", checkpoint = " << checkpoint << ")" << std::endl;
3392 *
3393  @endcode
3394 *
3395 * If the asynchronous writeback option is set we launch a background thread performing all the slow IO to disc. In that case we have to make sure that the background thread actually finished running. If not, we have to wait to for it to finish. We launch said background thread with <a
3396  href="https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/thread/async"><code>std::async()</code></a> that returns a <a
3397  href="https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/thread/future"><code>std::future</code></a> object. This <code>std::future</code> object contains the return value of the function, which is in our case simply <code>void</code> .
3398 *
3399 
3400 *
3401 *
3402 
3403 *
3404 * @code
3405  if (background_thread_state.valid())
3406  {
3407  TimerOutput::Scope timer(computing_timer, "main_loop
3408 *
3409 - stalled output");
3410  background_thread_state.wait();
3411  }
3412 *
3413  constexpr auto problem_dimension =
3414  ProblemDescription<dim>::problem_dimension;
3415 *
3416  @endcode
3417 *
3418 * At this point we make a copy of the state vector, run the schlieren postprocessor, and run DataOut<dim>::build_patches() The actual output code is standard: We create a DataOut instance, attach all data vectors we want to output and call DataOut<dim>::build_patches(). There is one twist, however. In order to perform asynchronous IO on a background thread we create the DataOut<dim> object as a shared pointer that we pass on to the worker thread to ensure that once we exit this function and the worker thread finishes the DataOut<dim> object gets destroyed again.
3419 *
3420 
3421 *
3422 *
3423 
3424 *
3425 * @code
3426  for (unsigned int i = 0; i < problem_dimension; ++i)
3427  {
3428  output_vector[i] = U[i];
3429  output_vector[i].update_ghost_values();
3430  }
3431 *
3432  schlieren_postprocessor.compute_schlieren(output_vector);
3433 *
3434  auto data_out = std::make_shared<DataOut<dim>>();
3435 *
3436  data_out->attach_dof_handler(offline_data.dof_handler);
3437 *
3438  const auto &component_names = ProblemDescription<dim>::component_names;
3439 *
3440  for (unsigned int i = 0; i < problem_dimension; ++i)
3441  data_out->add_data_vector(output_vector[i], component_names[i]);
3442 *
3443  data_out->add_data_vector(schlieren_postprocessor.schlieren,
3444  "schlieren_plot");
3445 *
3446  data_out->build_patches(discretization.mapping,
3447  discretization.finite_element.degree
3448 *
3449 - 1);
3450 *
3451  @endcode
3452 *
3453 * Next we create a lambda function for the background thread. We <a
3454  href="https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/lambda">capture</a> the <code>this</code> pointer as well as most of the arguments of the output function by value so that we have access to them inside the lambda function.
3455 *
3456 
3457 *
3458 * @code
3459  const auto output_worker = [this, name, t, cycle, checkpoint, data_out]() {
3460  if (checkpoint)
3461  {
3462  @endcode
3463 *
3464 * We checkpoint the current state by doing the precise inverse operation to what we discussed for the <a href="Resume">resume
3465  logic</a>:
3466 *
3467 
3468 *
3469 *
3470 
3471 *
3472 * @code
3473  const unsigned int i =
3474  discretization.triangulation.locally_owned_subdomain();
3475  std::string filename =
3476  name + "-checkpoint-" + Utilities::int_to_string(i, 4) + ".archive";
3477 *
3478  std::ofstream file(filename, std::ios::binary | std::ios::trunc);
3479 *
3480  boost::archive::binary_oarchive oa(file);
3481  oa << t << cycle;
3482  for (const auto &it1 : output_vector)
3483  for (const auto &it2 : it1)
3484  oa << it2;
3485  }
3486 *
3487  DataOutBase::VtkFlags flags(t,
3488  cycle,
3489  true,
3490  DataOutBase::VtkFlags::best_speed);
3491  data_out->set_flags(flags);
3492 *
3493  data_out->write_vtu_with_pvtu_record(
3494  "", name + "-solution", cycle, mpi_communicator, 6);
3495  };
3496 *
3497  @endcode
3498 *
3499 * If the asynchronous writeback option is set we launch a new background thread with the help of <a
3500  href="https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/thread/async"><code>std::async</code></a> function. The function returns a <a
3501  href="https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/thread/future"><code>std::future</code></a> object that we can use to query the status of the background thread. At this point we can return from the <code>output()</code> function and resume with the time stepping in the main loop
3502 *
3503 * - the thread will run in the background.
3504 *
3505 
3506 *
3507 * @code
3508  if (asynchronous_writeback)
3509  {
3510  background_thread_state = std::async(std::launch::async, output_worker);
3511  }
3512  else
3513  {
3514  output_worker();
3515  }
3516  }
3517 *
3518  } // namespace Step69
3519 *
3520  @endcode
3521 *
3522 * And finally, the main function.
3523 *
3524 
3525 *
3526 *
3527 
3528 *
3529 * @code
3530  int main(int argc, charargv[])
3531  {
3532  try
3533  {
3534  constexpr int dim = 2;
3535 *
3536  using namespace dealii;
3537  using namespace Step69;
3538 *
3539  Utilities::MPI::MPI_InitFinalize mpi_initialization(argc, argv);
3540 *
3541  MPI_Comm mpi_communicator(MPI_COMM_WORLD);
3542  MainLoop<dim> main_loop(mpi_communicator);
3543 *
3544  main_loop.run();
3545  }
3546  catch (std::exception &exc)
3547  {
3548  std::cerr << std::endl
3549  << std::endl
3550  << "----------------------------------------------------"
3551  << std::endl;
3552  std::cerr << "Exception on processing: " << std::endl
3553  << exc.what() << std::endl
3554  << "Aborting!" << std::endl
3555  << "----------------------------------------------------"
3556  << std::endl;
3557  return 1;
3558  }
3559  catch (...)
3560  {
3561  std::cerr << std::endl
3562  << std::endl
3563  << "----------------------------------------------------"
3564  << std::endl;
3565  std::cerr << "Unknown exception!" << std::endl
3566  << "Aborting!" << std::endl
3567  << "----------------------------------------------------"
3568  << std::endl;
3569  return 1;
3570  };
3571  }
3572  @endcode
3573 * <a name="Results"></a><a name="Results"></a><h1>Results</h1>
3574 *
3575 
3576 * Running the program with default parameters in release mode takes about 1minute on a 4 core machine (with hyperthreading):
3577 * @verbatim
3578 # mpirun
3579 *
3580 -np 4 ./step-69 | tee output
3581 Reading parameters and allocating objects... done
3582 *
3583  ####################################################
3584  ######### #########
3585  ######### create triangulation #########
3586  ######### #########
3587  ####################################################
3588 *
3589 Number of active cells: 36864
3590 *
3591  ####################################################
3592  ######### #########
3593  ######### compute offline data #########
3594  ######### #########
3595  ####################################################
3596 *
3597 Number of degrees of freedom: 37376
3598 *
3599  ####################################################
3600  ######### #########
3601  ######### set up time step #########
3602  ######### #########
3603  ####################################################
3604 *
3605  ####################################################
3606  ######### #########
3607  ######### interpolate initial values #########
3608  ######### #########
3609  ######### #########
3610  ####################################################
3611 *
3612 TimeLoop<dim>::interpolate_initial_values(t = 0)
3613 TimeLoop<dim>::output(t = 0, checkpoint = 0)
3614 *
3615  ####################################################
3616  ######### #########
3617  ######### enter main loop #########
3618  ######### #########
3619  ######### #########
3620  ####################################################
3621 *
3622  ####################################################
3623  ######### #########
3624  ######### Cycle 000001 (0.0%) #########
3625  ######### at time t = 0.00000000 #########
3626  ######### #########
3627  ####################################################
3628 *
3629 [...]
3630 *
3631  ####################################################
3632  ######### #########
3633  ######### Cycle 007553 (100.0%) #########
3634  ######### at time t = 3.99984036 #########
3635  ######### #########
3636  ####################################################
3637 *
3638 TimeLoop<dim>::output(t = 4.00038, checkpoint = 1)
3639 *
3640 +------------------------------------------------------------------------+------------+------------+
3641 | Total CPU time elapsed since start | 357s | |
3642 | | | |
3643 | Section | no. calls | CPU time | % of total |
3644 +------------------------------------------------------------+-----------+------------+------------+
3645 | discretization
3646 *
3647 - setup | 1 | 0.113s | 0% |
3648 | offline_data
3649 *
3650 - assemble lumped mass matrix, and c_ij | 1 | 0.167s | 0% |
3651 | offline_data
3652 *
3653 - compute |c_ij|, and n_ij | 1 | 0.00255s | 0% |
3654 | offline_data
3655 *
3656 - create sparsity pattern and set up matrices | 1 | 0.0224s | 0% |
3657 | offline_data
3658 *
3659 - distribute dofs | 1 | 0.0617s | 0% |
3660 | offline_data
3661 *
3662 - fix slip boundary c_ij | 1 | 0.0329s | 0% |
3663 | schlieren_postprocessor
3664 *
3665 - compute schlieren plot | 201 | 0.811s | 0.23% |
3666 | schlieren_postprocessor
3667 *
3668 - prepare scratch space | 1 | 7.6e-05s | 0% |
3669 | time_loop
3670 *
3671 - setup scratch space | 1 | 0.127s | 0% |
3672 | time_loop
3673 *
3674 - stalled output | 200 | 0.000685s | 0% |
3675 | time_step
3676 *
3677 - 1 compute d_ij | 7553 | 240s | 67% |
3678 | time_step
3679 *
3680 - 2 compute d_ii, and tau_max | 7553 | 11.5s | 3.2% |
3681 | time_step
3682 *
3683 - 3 perform update | 7553 | 101s | 28% |
3684 | time_step
3685 *
3686 - 4 fix boundary states | 7553 | 0.724s | 0.2% |
3687 | time_step
3688 *
3689 - prepare scratch space | 1 | 0.00245s | 0% |
3690 +------------------------------------------------------------+-----------+------------+------------+
3691 @endverbatim
3692 *
3693 * One thing that becomes evident is the fact that the program spends twothirds of the execution time computing the graph viscosity d_ij and about athird of the execution time in performing the update, where computing theflux @f$f(U)@f$ is the expensive operation. The preset default resolution isabout 37k gridpoints, which amounts to about 148k spatial degrees offreedom in 2D. An animated schlieren plot of the solution looks as follows:
3694 * <img src="https://www.dealii.org/images/steps/developer/step-69.coarse.gif" alt="" height="300">
3695 * It is evident that 37k gridpoints for the first-order method is nowherenear the resolution needed to resolve any flow features. For comparison,here is a "reference" computation with a second-order method and about 9.5Mgridpoints (<a href="https://github.com/conservation-laws/ryujin">github
3696 project page</a>):
3697 * <img src="https://www.dealii.org/images/steps/developer/step-69.2nd-order.t400.jpg" alt="" height="300">
3698 * So, we give the first-order method a second chance and run it with about2.4M gridpoints on a small compute server:
3699 * @verbatim
3700 # mpirun
3701 *
3702 -np 16 ./step-69 | tee output
3703 *
3704 [...]
3705 *
3706  ####################################################
3707  ######### #########
3708  ######### Cycle 070216 (100.0%) #########
3709  ######### at time t = 3.99999231 #########
3710  ######### #########
3711  ####################################################
3712 *
3713 TimeLoop<dim>::output(t = 4.00006, checkpoint = 1)
3714 *
3715 [...]
3716 *
3717 +------------------------------------------------------------------------+------------+------------+
3718 | Total wallclock time elapsed since start | 6.75e+03s | |
3719 | | | |
3720 | Section | no. calls | wall time | % of total |
3721 +------------------------------------------------------------+-----------+------------+------------+
3722 | discretization
3723 *
3724 - setup | 1 | 1.97s | 0% |
3725 | offline_data
3726 *
3727 - assemble lumped mass matrix, and c_ij | 1 | 1.19s | 0% |
3728 | offline_data
3729 *
3730 - compute |c_ij|, and n_ij | 1 | 0.0172s | 0% |
3731 | offline_data
3732 *
3733 - create sparsity pattern and set up matrices | 1 | 0.413s | 0% |
3734 | offline_data
3735 *
3736 - distribute dofs | 1 | 1.05s | 0% |
3737 | offline_data
3738 *
3739 - fix slip boundary c_ij | 1 | 0.252s | 0% |
3740 | schlieren_postprocessor
3741 *
3742 - compute schlieren plot | 201 | 1.82s | 0% |
3743 | schlieren_postprocessor
3744 *
3745 - prepare scratch space | 1 | 0.000497s | 0% |
3746 | time_loop
3747 *
3748 - setup scratch space | 1 | 1.45s | 0% |
3749 | time_loop
3750 *
3751 - stalled output | 200 | 0.00342s | 0% |
3752 | time_step
3753 *
3754 - 1 compute d_ij | 70216 | 4.38e+03s | 65% |
3755 | time_step
3756 *
